HPV is a DNA virus belonging to the Papillomaviridae family.

Tropism: Selectively infects epithelial cells of skin and mucous membranes.

Morphology

  • Non-enveloped virus, 50–55 nm in size.
  • Icosahedral capsid containing circular double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

Viral Genome

Early (E) Region: Includes E1-E7 genes coding for nonstructural proteins.

  • E1 and E2 Proteins: Regulate viral DNA replication.
  • E4 Protein: Disrupts cytokeratins to facilitate the release of the virus.
  • E5 Protein: Contributes to the formation of perinuclear vacuoles, leading to cytoplasmic “halos.”
  • E6 Protein: Promotes degradation of the p53 tumor-suppressor protein.
  • E7 Protein: Inhibits retinoblastoma protein, contributing to oncogenesis.

Late (L) Region: L1 and L2 genes code for structural capsid proteins.

  • Types: Over 100 HPV types, classified by DNA sequences in the L1 region.
  • L1 capsid protein is used for making vaccines.

HPV Mechanism of Oncogenesis
  • E6 Protein:
    • Promotes degradation of p53, blocking apoptosis and inhibiting p53-driven activation of tumor suppressor gene p21.
  • E7 Protein:
    • Inhibits the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor gene through direct RB inhibition and by interfering with p53 and p21 functions.
  • HPV infection alone is insufficient for malignancy; factors such as co-transfection with v-fos DNA, genetic mutations (e.g., mutated RAS gene), & environmental influences (e.g., smoking, microbial co-infections, dietary deficiencies, hormonal changes) enhance cancer risk.

questions.text: What is the underlying factor responsible for inducing aplastic crisis in individuals with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
 
 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis (Option D):
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Parvovirus

Morphology

  • Simplest animal viruses infecting humans, responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).
  • Smallest viruses (18–26 nm in size).
  • Non-enveloped with icosahedral symmetry.
  • Only DNA viruses with single-stranded DNA.
  • Dependent on host cell enzymes for replication.

Pathogenesis
  • Exclusively infects humans.
  • Transmission:
  • Primarily through the respiratory route.
  • Blood transfusion.
  • Transplacental transmission.
  • Target Cells: Tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in adult bone marrow and fetal liver.
  • Receptor Binding: Binds to blood group P antigen on RBC surface.
  • Effects: Leads to RBC destruction and inhibition of erythropoiesis, potentially causing anemia.

Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) (Option A )
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia. (Option B)

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: Oral hairy leukoplakia is associated with which of the following infections?
Molluscum contagiosum is caused by
questions.explanation:
Poxviruses

Poxviruses are the largest viruses that infect vertebrates.

Morphology

  • Poxviruses measure approximately 400 nm in length and 230 nm in diameter, making them visible under a light microscope.
  • Poxviruses are typically brick-shaped or ellipsoid.
  • They possess an envelope consisting of two lipoprotein membranes (outer and inner), and the outer membrane features ridges.
  • The envelope encases a core, along with two structures of unknown function known as lateral bodies.
  • The core or nucleocapsid is biconcave and shaped like a dumbbell.
  • Poxviruses contain a single linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome.
  • They are unique among DNA viruses for replicating in the cytoplasm.

Human-Important poxviruses
  • Variola is the causative agent of smallpox, the first disease to be eradicated globally.
  • Vaccinia: Used as a vaccine for smallpox.
  • Molluscum contagiosum Virus: Causes warty lesions known as molluscum contagiosum.

Genera classification

  • Orthopoxvirus: Smallpox, monkeypox, vaccinia.
  • Molluscipoxvirus: Molluscum contagiosum.
  • Parapoxvirus: Milker’s nodules, bovine papular stomatitis viruses, etc.
  • Capripoxvirus: Sheeppox, goatpox, lumpy skin disease, etc.
  • Avipoxvirus: Fowlpox, pigeon pox, etc.
  • Leporipoxvirus: Myxoma, hare fibroma, etc.
  • Suipoxvirus: Swinepox virus.
  • Yatapoxvirus: Tanapox, Yabapox viruses.

Molluscum contagiosum

Molluscum contagiosum virus is an obligate human poxvirus known for producing characteristic skin lesions.

Clinical manifestations

Lesions:

  • Dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions (2–5 mm in size) with a dimple at the center.
  • Lesions can appear singly or in clusters, located anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles.
  • Lesions are umbilicated.
  • Genital lesions are commonly observed in adults.
  • Lesions typically resolve on their own within 3–4 months.

Transmission

  • Primarily affects children, transmitted through direct and indirect contact (e.g., barbers, shared towels, swimming pools).
  • Rare instances of sexual transmission have been reported in young adults.

Laboratory diagnosis

Molluscum bodies:

  • Characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions were observed in skin scrapings stained with histopathological stains.

Confirmation methods:

  • Electron microscopy
  • PCR

Cultivation:

  • The virus cannot be propagated in tissue culture, embryonated eggs, or animals.

Treatment
  • Surgical removal of the lesions by ablation (by cryotherapy or laser therapy) is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Cidofovir has been shown to have some efficacy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough for 5 days. Chest X-ray findings suggest the diagnosis. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

Refers to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions.

Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B,
    • Adenovirus,
    • Respiratory syncytial virus,
    • Measles.

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper Respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea,
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Mild cough,
  • Low-grade fever.

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough,
  • Hoarseness,
  • Inspiratory stridor,
  • Fever may reach 39-40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent.
  • The child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright.
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week.

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice,
  • Coryza,
  • Normal to moderately inflamed pharynx.
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate.
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation seen only in complete airway obstruction.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment.
  • Mild croup: Single dose dexamethasone.
  • Moderate to severe croup: Nebulized epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Used for moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress and hypoxia.
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
    • Dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg single dose; as low as 0.15 mg/kg may be effective.
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the common cause for diarrhea and dehydration in children:
Covid-19 can be prevented through all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Pathogenesis of COVID-19

Host Cell Entry
  • Binding: Spike glycoprotein (S) attaches to angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE-2) receptors on lung type II alveolar cells.
  • Cleavage: Host proteases (e.g., TMPRSS2) cleave the spike protein, facilitating viral entry via the endosomal pathway.

Initial Inflammatory Response
  • Influenza-like Illness (ILI): Infection of the pharyngeal epithelium initiates ILI.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
  • Damage to Alveolar Cells: Impaired type II alveolar cells decrease pulmonary surfactant, causing alveolar collapse and fluid retention.
  • Cytokine Storm: Increased immune cytokine release leads to:
    • Tissue damage and necrosis.
    • Impaired gas exchange and hypoxia.
    • Endothelial damage and microvascular thrombosis.
    • Pulmonary oedema and ground-glass opacities on imaging.
    • Fibrosis and respiratory failure.

Multiorgan Failure
  • Elevated cytokines may harm other organs, resulting in sepsis, septic shock, and acute kidney/cardiac injury.

Risk Factors for Severe Disease
  • Demographics: Age > 60 years.
  • Comorbidities: Diabetes, hypertension, COPD, CKD and cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic test for monkeypox?
questions.explanation:
Monkeypox infections
  • The monkeypox virus belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus.
  • Monkeypox is a rare zoonotic infection first recognized in captive monkeys in 1958.

Transmission
  • Infection likely occurs through direct contact with wild animals.
  • The exact primary reservoir host remains unidentified, but species such as squirrels, rabbits, and rodents can be infected.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms resemble those of smallpox but are generally milder.
  • Fever and rash.
  • Lymphadenopathy is a prominent feature in most cases, unlike in smallpox or chickenpox.

Complications
  • Respiratory distress
  • Secondary bacterial infections

Vaccination

The vaccinia vaccine can offer protection against monkeypox or lessen its severity.

Human-to-Human transmission
  • Transmission between humans is considered limited.
  • Estimates suggest that only about 15% of close contacts of infected individuals become infected.

Diagnosis
  • The CDC recommends the collection of two specimens, each from multiple lesions from different locations.
  • Confirmed via isolation in viral culture or by PCR for mpox virus DNA from a patient specimen.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pain in the genital area. On examination, there is a painful vesicle. Further examination also reveals tender lymphadenopathy. What is the likely diagnosis?
A person is bitten by a dog. The dog and the person are fully immunized against rabies. There is a laceration at the site of the bite. What would you advise to the person?
questions.explanation:
Agent factor
  • Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate
  • Lyssavirus type 1
    • Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family).
  • Two Types of Viruses:
    • Street virus:
      • Cause natural infection (Rabies)
      • Variable incubation period (7 days-months)
    • Fixed virus:
      • Fixed incubation period (5-7 days)
      • For vaccine production.
      • It does not demonstrate Negri bodies.

Host factors
  • Occupation
    • Dog handlers
    • Forest workers
    • Veterinarians.

Transmission
  • Incubation period: 2-8 weeks
  • Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey or Wild animal (all need vaccination)
  • Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission.
  • Rodent bites don't require vaccination.
  • Human bite is a very dangerous bite (no documented cases yet)
  • In India:
    • Urban Rabies is very common.
    • Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands)

questions.text: Which statement about rubella is incorrect ?

options.label: A
options.text: It is one of the teratogenic TORCH infections

options.label: B
options.text: Causes maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads caudally to involve the trunk and extremities

questions.explanation:
CONGENITAL RUBELLA SYNDROME

Definition
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs in infants who have contracted rubella from their mothers while in utero.
  • The most likely time for this to occur is between 8-10 weeks of gestation.
  • After birth, these babies can transmit the virus to others for a period of 12–18 months.

Dermatological presentation
  • Blueberry Muffin Rash (Option D ruled out)
  • Forchheimer Spots- small, red or purple spots that can appear on the soft palate

Ophthalmic Defects
  • Cataracts
  • Microphthalmia
  • Glaucoma
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Chorioretinitis

Auditory Defects
  • Sensorineural deafness

Cardiac Defects
  • Peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis
  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Ventricular septal defects

Craniofacial Defects
  • Microcephaly

Other Infant Presentations
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Interstitial pneumonitis
  • Radiolucency in the long bones

 

Diagnosis

 
  • Hemagglutination inhibition test (HAI) is the commonly preferred test.
  • Presence of IgM antibodies shortly after birth.
  • Presence of IgG antibodies lasting >6 months.
  • IgM positive implies in-utero infection because IgM antibodies cannot pass from mother to child through the placenta.

questions.text: A child presents with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease

questions.correct_answer: A. Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease
questions.explanation:
Vaso-occlusive crisis

Caused by obstruction of the microcirculation by sickled RBCs

Acute chest syndrome

Caused by vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs

Sequestration crisis (spleen or liver)

Obstruction of splenic veins causes sequestration of peripheral blood in an engorged spleen

Infectious crisis

Caused by increased susceptibility to infection by encapsulated organisms

Aplastic crisis

Results from cessation of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow, usually following infections

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with fever and retro-orbital headache for 2 days. Her Tourniquet test and NS1 antigen are positive, suggesting Dengue infection. Which of the following findings qualifies as a severe dengue criterion?
questions.explanation:
Uncategorised fever

  • No typical features

Break bone fever

(Classical dengue fever/ acute viral infection)

 
  • Retro orbital pain
  • Arthralgia
  • Severe myalgia and headache
  • Bimodal presentation of fever:
    • 39-40°C, peaks on days 1-2
    • Resurges: day 5-6
    • Recovery: day 7-10.
  • Rash: pin-point eruptions on the face, neck and chest followed by maculopapular or scarlatiniform on 3rd or 4th day.

Dengue haemorrhagic syndrome
  • Dengue fever + hemorrhagic manifestations(bleeding from any orifice)
  • Rash: Maculopapular/ Rubelliform
  • Lab diagnosis
    • 20% increase in hematocrit
    • Thrombocytopenia (<1 lac)
  • Clinical diagnosis
    • Tourniquet test- >10 petechiae/ sq inch area

Dengue shock syndrome
  • Pulse pressure - <20 mmHg
  • Mean systolic pressure - <90mmHg: adults, <80 mmHg: children.

Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus
    • linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.
  • Encephalitis
  • GBS
  • Stroke

Cardiomyopathy
  • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis

 
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever

All of the following:

  • Acute onset of fever
  • 2-7 days duration
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations
    • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae
    • Ecchymosis
    • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm.
  • Plasma leakage
    • Rising hematocrit
      • Hemoconcentration >20%
    • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia)

Dengue Shock Syndrome
  • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock
  • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness
  • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80)
  • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults)

questions.text: An 18-day-old baby presents with fever and cough. On examination, vesicles are observed over the trunk and upper limb. The mother had genital ulcers one year ago, which have since resolved. Biopsy of the vesicles reveals multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
EBV (Epstein Barr virus)

  • Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.
  • Ballerina skirt appearance.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

  • The presence of inclusion bodies gives the characteristic “Owl-eye appearance”.

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8)

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of diseases and their corresponding populations related to parvovirus is incorrect? 1. Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease 2. Viral envelop - Naked virus 3. Erythema infectiosum - infants 4. Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE
questions.explanation:
Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:


 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.explanation:

1st trimester

2nd trimester

Parvovirus

3rd trimester

Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis.

During delivery

Infection

Pathogen & Transmission

Clinical Features

Toxoplasmosis

Toxoplasma gondii (transplacental from infected mother, cat feces, undercooked meat)

Classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications; anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, seizures, intellectual disability

Varicella

(Option B ruled out)

Varicella-zoster virus (aerosols, direct contact, transplacental)

Congenital varicella syndrome: skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, neurodevelopmental delay

Syphilis

Treponema pallidum (sexual transmission, transplacental, peripartum)

Stillbirth, Hutchinson triad (notched teeth, interstitial keratitis, deafness), skeletal abnormalities

Parvovirus B19

Parvovirus B19 (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Hydrops fetalis, neurodevelopmental defects, fetal anemia

Rubella

(Option D ruled out)

Rubella virus (respiratory droplets, transplacental)

Congenital rubella syndrome: sensorineural deafness, cataracts, congenital heart disease, hepatosplenomegaly

Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

(Option A ruled out)

CMV (body fluids, blood transfusion, organ transplant, transplacental, peripartum, breast milk)

Leading cause of non-genetic congenital hearing loss, petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, neurodevelopmental deficits

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1 & HSV-2)

HSV (direct contact, mucosal exposure, peripartum)

Neonatal herpes: vesicular rash, encephalitis, seizures, bulging fontanelle, viral sepsis, organ failure

questions.text: A patient presented with high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.correct_answer: C. CSF PCR for viral DNA
questions.explanation:
HSV Encephalitis
  • Herpesviruses: Large, double-stranded DNA viruses; 8 types affect humans (HHV-1 to HHV-8).
  • HSV Types:
    • HSV-1: Most common in adults & children; sporadic, non-seasonal.
    • HSV-2: More common in neonates & immunocompromised individuals.

Etiology
  • Causative Agents: HSV-1 (90%), HSV-2 (10%).
  • Structure: Enveloped, icosahedral, double-stranded DNA virus.
  • Host Cell Entry: Via nectin-1 and HVEM receptors on neurons.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Primary infection: HSV infects skin/mucosa, enters neurons, and travels retrogradely to ganglia.
    • Latency: Controlled by immune mechanisms (histone deposition, cytokines).
    • Reactivation: Can spread to CNS via trigeminal or olfactory nerves.

Pathophysiology
  • Transmission: Close contact; HSV-1 → oral, HSV-2 → genital.
  • Brain Invasion Routes:
    1. Oropharyngeal infection → Trigeminal/Olfactory nerve spread.
    2. Reactivation in ganglia → CNS spread.
    3. Latent HSV in the brain reactivates.
  • Affected Areas: Temporal lobes, limbic system → hemorrhagic necrosis.
  • Immunosuppression Risks: Natalizumab, TNF-α inhibitors, whole-brain radiation.

Clinical Presentation
  • Prodrome: Fever, malaise, headache, nausea.
  • Typical Features:
    • CNS signs: Confusion, seizures, focal deficits, personality changes.
    • Behavioral syndromes: Hypomania, Klüver-Bucy, amnesia.
    • Other findings: Incontinence, dermatomal rash, Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • Neonatal HSE:
    • Presents at 1–3 weeks with irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, tremors, seizures.
    • Herpetic skin lesions, thrombocytopenia, liver dysfunction may be present.
  • Immunocompromised Patients: Atypical/subtle presentation, fewer focal deficits.

Histopathology
  • Gross Findings: Hemorrhagic necrosis in medial temporal and inferior frontal lobes.
  • Microscopic Findings:
    • Early: Neuronal ischemia, capillary dilation.
    • Cowdry type A inclusions: Eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions in neurons.
    • Late (>3 weeks): Necrosis, gliosis, inflammation.
  • Atypical in Immunocompromised: Less inflammation, persistent viral antigens.

Evaluation
  • CSF Analysis (Gold Standard):
    • ↑ WBCs (lymphocytic pleocytosis), ↑ protein, normal glucose.
    • HSV PCR: 96% sensitive, 99% specific.
    • Repeat PCR if negative within 72 hours in high-suspicion cases.
    • HSV IgM in CSF is useful if PCR is unavailable or delayed.
  • Imaging:
    • CT: Initial test; may be normal early, later shows hypodensities, hemorrhage.
    • MRI (Best Test): Temporal lobe hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR, sparing basal ganglia.
  • Other Tests:
    • CBC, metabolic panel.
    • HSV PCR in blood useful in neonates & immunocompromised.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and rash. Urine examination shows cells with an "owl-eye" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cytomegalovirus

General Characteristics
  • Herpesvirus (HHV-5), widespread prevalence.
  • Often asymptomatic in healthy individuals but severe in immunocompromised and congenital infections.
  • Remains latent post-infection and may reactivate.
  • Linked to mucoepidermoid carcinoma and possibly prostate cancer.
  • Transmission: Blood transfusions, organ transplantation, breastfeeding, close contact, perinatal, and sexual routes.
  • Reactivation occurs in immunocompromised individuals, increasing morbidity and mortality.

Pathophysiology
  • Persists in myeloid cells, reactivates with immune suppression.
  • Controlled mainly by cytotoxic T-cell immunity.
  • Lifelong immune burden, affecting T-cell surveillance.

Clinical Manifestations
  • Immunocompetent patients: Often asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like syndrome (fever, rash, leukocytosis).
  • Immunocompromised patients: Can cause severe organ-specific disease:
  • CMV hepatitis → Risk of fulminant liver failure
  • CMV retinitis → “Pizza pie” fundoscopic appearance
  • CMV esophagitis, colitis, pneumonitis, polyradiculopathy, encephalitis, transverse myelitis

Diagnosis
  • Quantitative PCR: Preferred for viral detection.
  • Histopathology (CMV inclusion bodies): Gold standard.
  • Serology: Used for pre-transplant risk assessment but not for acute infection diagnosis.
  • CMV-negative blood transfusions reserved for neonates and immunocompromised patients.
  • Ganciclovir resistance testing is routine in transplant centers.

Management
  • Immunocompetent patients: Self-limiting, only symptomatic treatment required.
  • Immunocompromised & severe cases: Require antivirals (ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir).
  • Prophylaxis: CMV-negative recipients of CMV-positive organ transplants should receive valganciclovir or ganciclovir with serological monitoring.
  • Antiviral toxicity must be weighed against benefits.

questions.text: The HIV genome requires which of the following to initiate the process of entering the host cell membrane?
questions.explanation:
Structural Genes (3)

Non-structural Genes (6)

gag Gene: Codes for the virus's core and shell components. The precursor protein p55 is cleaved into:

  • p18: Matrix or shell antigen.
  • p24 and p15: Core antigens.

Essential Regulatory Genes:

  • tat: Transcriptional transactivator. Tat recruits cellular transcription factors to the HIV-1 promoter.
  • nef: Negative factor. Regulatory protein that affects HIV-1 virulence
  • rev: Regulator of virus gene. The HIV-1 Rev protein regulates post-transcriptional processing of viral mRNAs

pol Gene: Codes for viral enzymes, including reverse transcriptase, protease, and integrase. It is expressed as a precursor protein that is cleaved into:

  • p31: Integrase.
  • p51 and p66: Reverse transcriptase.

Accessory Regulatory Genes:

  • vif: Viral infectivity factor.
  • vpr: Involved in viral replication.
  • vpu: Enhances the maturation and release of progeny virus from cells.

env Gene: Codes for the envelope glycoprotein gp160, which is cleaved into:

  • gp120: Main receptor that binds to CD4 on host cells, initiating infection.
  • gp41: Fusion protein facilitating entry into the host cell.

questions.text: A PLHIV came with multiple dog bites with a punctured wound. Choose the correctmanagement:
questions.explanation:
Category

Exposure Type

Management

Category I
  • Touching or feeding animals
  • Licking of intact skin
  • Ensure proper hygiene
  • No treatment required

Category II
  • Nibbling on uncovered skin
  • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding
  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water

Rabies vaccination:

  • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14
  • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3
  • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required

Category III
  • Bites or scratches with bleeding
  • Licks on broken skin
  • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose)
  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes.
  • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours.
  • Rabies vaccination:
    • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14
    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3
  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):
    • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG
    • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG
      • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses)
      • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM
      • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days).
      • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound.

Required for unvaccinated individuals

Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

questions.text: A Tzanck smear prepared from a vesicle shows multinucleated giant cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Herpes Simplex Virus:

  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
  • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8):

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Togaviru

questions.text: Identify the organism ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Hantaviru

Family
  • Hantaviridae
Genus
  • Orthohantavirus (formerly Hantavirus).
Transmission
  • Primarily transmitted to humans through contact with the urine, feces, or saliva of infected rodents (rodent-borne). - Some hantaviruses can also be transmitted through bites from infected rodents, and a few through person-to-person transmission (rare).
Natural Reservoir
  • Rodents, especially deer mice, bank voles, and other species depending on the geographic location. - Reservoir hosts typically remain asymptomatic.
Geographical Distribution
  • Worldwide, with different hantaviruses found in specific regions. - Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome (HPS) in the Americas, and Hemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome (HFRS) in Eurasia.
Clinical Syndromes
  • Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome (HPS) in the Americas, characterized by respiratory distress and a high mortality rate. - Hemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome (HFRS) in Eurasia, presenting with fever, renal failure, and hemorrhagic manifestations.
Pathogenesis
  • Primary target organs include the lungs (HPS) or kidneys (HFRS). - Severity of illness varies among hantaviruses.
Clinical Presentation
  • Early symptoms may include fever, fatigue, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms. - Severe cases progress to respiratory or renal failure with potential hemorrhagic manifestations.
Incubation Period
  • Typically ranges from 1 to 5 weeks, with symptoms appearing after exposure to the virus.
Diagnosis
  • Laboratory testing includes serological assays (IgM and IgG antibodies) and molecular tests such as PCR. - Chest imaging for HPS cases.
Treatment
  • No specific antiviral treatment for hantavirus infections.- Supportive care, including mechanical ventilation for severe respiratory cases (HPS), and renal replacement therapy for severe renal cases (HFRS).
Prevention and Control
  • Minimize contact with rodents and their excreta in areas where hantaviruses are known to circulate. - Use protective measures when cleaning or working in environments where rodents may be present. - Rodent control measures in and around living spaces.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusion s are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Herpes simplex:

Inclusion Bodies and Viruses Producing Them

Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

  • Negri bodies – rabies virus
  • Paschen body – variola virus
  • Guamieri bodies – vaccinia virus
  • Bollinger bodies – fowlpox virus
  • Molluscum bodies – molluscum contagiosum virus
  • Perinuclear cytoplasmic body – reovirus

Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

Cowdry type A inclusions

  • Torres body – yellow fever virus
  • Lipschutz body – herpes simplex virus

Cowdry type B inclusions

  • Poliovirus
  • Adenovirus

Intracytoplasmic and Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

  • Owl’s eye appearance – cytomegalovirus
  • Measles virus
